</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Economy: </strong></span><span>Americans are making bread and not much else. U.S. manufacturing production in March suffered its </span><span><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-economy-manufacturing/u-s-manufacturing-output-posts-largest-drop-since-1946-idUSKCN21X1X5?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">biggest monthly drop</a></span><span> since 1946. Makers of cars and auto parts took the biggest tumble, down 28%.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Stimulus: </strong></span><span>The IRS </span><span><a href="https://www.irs.gov/coronavirus/get-my-payment?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">launched a website</a></span><span> to help you track your stimulus payment. And it appears as though the $350 billion in small business loans is close to running dry. More than </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/15/small-business-rescue-loans-top-296-billion-rapidly-nearing-the-programs-funding-limit.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$296 billion in loans</a></span><span> had been approved by yesterday afternoon, the SBA disclosed.</span>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RETAIL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/15/coronavirus-pandemic-rocked-retail-sector-march?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
No One Be Shopping
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="retail sales in Q1 illustration" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC82MDQvcmV0YWlsX3NhbGVzX2luX3ExLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In the coronavirus era, new economic data is like looking at the cockroach you whacked with a magazine. It’s unpleasant, but you have to do it just in case. So we’ll deliver yesterday’s March retail sales numbers in the most digestible ways we can think of.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Generally, the sector was like a dolphin </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/15/us-retail-sales-march-2020.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">plunging into the sea</a></span><span>—overall sales dropped 8.7% monthly, the biggest dip since the government started keeping track in 1992.  </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">To break it down, let’s start with the bright spots. </strong>March grocery sales bounced almost 27%.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Health and personal care stores and general merchandise stores also fared well, growing sales 4.3% and 6.4%, respectively. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Some economists said grocery’s surge may not last now that we’re all stocked up on kimchi. But grocery has long been considered recession-proof, and with restaurants closed there’s reason to believe demand will stay strong. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Now for the darker spots</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Before we get there, remember that March hit the retail sector with a double whammy: 1) stores shuttered to comply with government orders and 2) layoffs from other industries hurt consumer spending. But again, we’ll try to keep it pleasant. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Clothing sales were like a </span><span><a href="https://www.marketwatch.com/story/coronavirus-brings-nighmarish-march-for-most-retailers-but-one-group-smashes-sales-records-2020-04-15?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">maple leaf drifting off its bough</a></span><span>...halfway to the ground. They dropped 50%. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Furniture/home furnishings</span><span><strong style="color:#000"> </strong></span><span>and food services/drinking places were like a pair of pelicans diving for fish, both dropping nearly 27%. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>March may have come out like a lion, but we all know April is the cruelest month. Barclays Chief U.S. Economist Michael Gapen told Bloomberg, “the April data is likely to be even worse because for a good half of March, things were still open.”</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TECH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/15/apple-looks-old-iphone-new-release?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Tim Cooked Up a New iPhone
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="new iPhone" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC82MDUvbmV3X2lwaG9uZS5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Apple</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The iPhone SE <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/4/15/21221918/iphone-se-announcement-apple-price-specs-release-date-features?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">is back</a> and if you know what the “SE” stands for then congrats on your job at Apple. Clocking in at a refreshingly svelte $399, it brings back some fan favorite design elements with a few notable exceptions.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">What’s included...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Apple’s A13 Bionic chip</strong></span><span>, the same one found in the latest iPhone 11 and 11 Pro. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Portrait mode</strong></span><span>, but don't try it on your pet. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">A home button</strong></span><span> with Touch ID and haptic feedback. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And what’s not…</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">5G connectivity</strong></span><span>, more on that later.  </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Face ID</strong></span><span>, which could be a plus because, you know, masks.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">The smaller size </strong></span><span>of </span><span><a href="https://www.theverge.com/2016/3/24/11295536/apple-iphone-se-small-phone-4-inch-vs-6s?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">past SE models</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Apple will likely unveil its flagship iPhone 12 line this fall and yes, they will be 5G compatible. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Apple is releasing cheaper phones for the first time since 2016 because 1) budget-conscious buyers aren’t <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/apple-iphone/apple-releases-budget-iphone-se-priced-at-399-as-coronavirus-stalls-economy-idUSL2N2C22S0?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">upgrading flagship models</a> as often and 2) they attract new consumers into the services ecosystem Apple's intent on growing. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BANKING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/15/banks-rainy-day-funds-got-whole-lot-larger-q1?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Banks Stuff Money Under the Mattress
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The beginning of earnings season highlighted just how bumpy the road ahead will be for the U.S.’ major banks—let's hope they peed before getting in the car.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A white glove lineup including JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, Bank of America, Citigroup, and Goldman Sachs disclosed this week that they <a href="https://apnews.com/66b6a574386b82357167e1d5b72fffbe?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">bolstered their rainy day funds</a> by a combined $20 billion in Q1. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Why? </strong></span><span>With so many households and businesses on the brink due to COVID-19 layoffs and closures, a deluge of loan defaults looks inevitable. Banks, from their consumer to investment divisions, are </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/goldman-sachs-quarterly-profit-falls-46-11586950665?mod=hp_lead_pos2&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">doomsday prepping</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And execs think those piles they set aside to account for bad loans could get even bigger next quarter, further proof Wall Street <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/14/business/bank-earnings-jpmorgan-wells-fargo.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">has its doubts</a> that the $2.2 trillion relief package D.C. just doled out is enough to steady everyday Americans’ finances.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">With that in mind, BofA, Citi, and Goldman all copped to profit drops north of 40% in Q1 yesterday. Q2 might look tanner, but not much better.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENERGY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/15/iea-projects-unprecedented-oil-demand-collapse?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Worst Year in the History of Global Oil Markets
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="geopolitics" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNTMvb2lsLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-15/oil-glut-may-overwhelm-storage-despite-opec-cut-iea-says?sref=1crrKBaO&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">That’s what we’re headed for</a>, according to an International Energy Agency (IEA) report released yesterday. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How we got here: </strong>Lockdowns intended to limit the spread of the coronavirus crushed oil demand. Canceled vacations and business trips mean no need for fuel to propel planes. No one is commuting or attending events, so no one’s buying gas. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>IEA said the world is experiencing the biggest annual demand decline in history, with nearly a decade of demand growth set to be wiped out. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Crude prices fell to their lowest point since 2002 yesterday.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Oil producers have tried to limit the fallout.</strong> On Sunday, OPEC+ reached a historic agreement to cut production in a last-ditch attempt to stabilize prices. That may help a little bit, but there is “no feasible agreement that could cut supply by enough” to counteract the demand collapse, the IEA says. Most analysts agree.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">One stubborn optimist: </strong>Energy data provider Kayrros says the cuts are steep enough to avoid overwhelming storage capacity. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
INTERNATIONAL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/15/germany-set-ease-lockdown-restrictions?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Germany Set to Return in Fits and Stuttgarts
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Europe’s largest economy is ready to emerge from hibernation. German Chancellor Angela Merkel said the country will begin to <a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-52299358?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">slowly ease lockdown restrictions</a>—some shops can open next week and schools will return starting May 4. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The country has suffered more than 3,200 reported COVID-19 deaths. But Merkel said it’s achieved "fragile intermediate success" in controlling the pandemic. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This won’t be your Germany of 2019. The businesses that open will have to follow strict social distancing and hygiene precautions. Germans are <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-germany/germany-edges-out-of-lockdown-with-partial-opening-of-shops-schools-idUSKCN21X0X6?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">strongly encouraged</a> to wear face masks when riding public transportation or going shopping. And large public gatherings are still banned until Aug. 31. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Europe is beginning to recover. Spain’s construction and manufacturing workers are back in action, as are many stores in Austria and some in Italy. Kids under 11 are going back to school in Denmark. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">A sobering bottom line, via Merkel: </strong>“It is a fragile situation in which caution is required, not exuberance.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we’re here...</strong>the WHO has set <a href="https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2020/04/15/834021103/who-sets-6-conditions-for-ending-a-coronavirus-lockdown?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">six conditions</a> for relaxing coronavirus lockdowns. Extreme boredom isn’t one of them.</p>

</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Want to read fiction: </strong></span><span>Retail Brew writer Halie recommends </span><span><a href="https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/123952/the-tigers-wife-by-tea-obreht/" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>The Tiger’s Wife</em></a></span><span>, creative director Blake thinks you should read </span><span><a href="https://www.harpercollins.com/9780062073495/murder-on-the-orient-express/" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Murder on the Orient Express</em></a></span><span>, copywriter Sydney thinks </span><span><a href="https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/110437/let-the-great-world-spin-by-colum-mccann/" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Let The Great World Spin</em></a></span><span> is a beautiful read, and dailly writer Toby says </span><span><a href="https://www.littlebrown.com/titles/chad-harbach/the-art-of-fielding/9780316204729/" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>The Art of Fielding</em></a></span><span> is “real real good.” </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Want to cook:</strong></span><span> Learn from top chefs on </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-15/best-youtube-cooking-video-babish-pick-up-limes-bon-appetit" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">YouTube</a></span><span>.</span>

<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">

</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Want to get smarter: </strong></span><span>Listen to Geoffrey Garrett, dean of UPenn’s prestigious Wharton School, explain what’s at stake for our globalized economy in the wake of COVID-19 on our podcast </span><span><em>Business Casual</em></span><span>. U.S. manufacturing production in March suffered its \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-economy-manufacturing/u-s-manufacturing-output-posts-largest-drop-since-1946-idUSKCN21X1X5?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebiggest monthly drop\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e since 1946. Makers of cars and auto parts took the biggest tumble, down 28%.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eStimulus: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe IRS \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.irs.gov/coronavirus/get-my-payment?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elaunched a website\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e to help you track your stimulus payment. And it appears as though the $350 billion in small business loans is close to running dry. style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn the coronavirus era, new economic data is like looking at the cockroach you whacked with a magazine. It’s unpleasant, but you have to do it just in case. So we’ll deliver yesterday’s March retail sales numbers in the most digestible ways we can think of.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eGenerally, the sector was like a dolphin \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/15/us-retail-sales-march-2020.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eplunging into the sea\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e—overall sales dropped 8.7% monthly, the biggest dip since the government started keeping track in 1992.  \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eTo break it down, let’s start with the bright spots. \u003c/strong\u003eMarch grocery sales bounced almost 27%.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHealth and personal care stores and general merchandise stores also fared well, growing sales 4.3% and 6.4%, respectively. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSome economists said grocery’s surge may not last now that we’re all stocked up on kimchi. But grocery has long been considered recession-proof, and with restaurants closed there’s reason to believe demand will stay strong. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eNow for the darker spots\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBefore we get there, remember that March hit the retail sector with a double whammy: 1) stores shuttered to comply with government orders and 2) layoffs from other industries hurt consumer spending. But again, we’ll try to keep it pleasant. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eClothing sales were like a \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.marketwatch.com/story/coronavirus-brings-nighmarish-march-for-most-retailers-but-one-group-smashes-sales-records-2020-04-15?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emaple leaf drifting off its bough\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e...halfway to the ground. They dropped 50%. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eFurniture/home furnishings\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eand food services/drinking places were like a pair of pelicans diving for fish, both dropping nearly 27%. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eMarch may have come out like a lion, but we all know April is the cruelest month. Barclays Chief U.S. Economist Michael Gapen told Bloomberg, “the April data is likely to be even worse because for a good half of March, things were still open.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F04%2F15%2Fcoronavirus-pandemic-rocked-retail-sector-march\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block; style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe beginning of earnings season highlighted just how bumpy the road ahead will be for the U.S.’ major banks—let's hope they peed before getting in the car.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eA white glove lineup including JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, Bank of America, Citigroup, and Goldman Sachs disclosed this week that they \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/66b6a574386b82357167e1d5b72fffbe?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebolstered their rainy day funds\u003c/a\u003e by a combined $20 billion in Q1. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWith so many households and businesses on the brink due to COVID-19 layoffs and closures, a deluge of loan defaults looks inevitable. Banks, from their consumer to investment divisions, are \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/goldman-sachs-quarterly-profit-falls-46-11586950665?mod=hp_lead_pos2\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edoomsday prepping\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd execs think those piles they set aside to account for bad loans could get even bigger next quarter, further proof Wall Street \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/14/business/bank-earnings-jpmorgan-wells-fargo.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehas its doubts\u003c/a\u003e that the $2.2 trillion relief package D.C. just doled out is enough to steady everyday Americans’ finances.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWith that in mind, BofA, Citi, and Goldman all copped to profit drops north of 40% in Q1 yesterday. rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eThat’s what we’re headed for\u003c/a\u003e, according to an International Energy Agency (IEA) report released yesterday. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow we got here: \u003c/strong\u003eLockdowns intended to limit the spread of the coronavirus crushed oil demand. Canceled vacations and business trips mean no need for fuel to propel planes. No one is commuting or attending events, so no one’s buying gas. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIEA said the world is experiencing the biggest annual demand decline in history, with nearly a decade of demand growth set to be wiped out. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCrude prices fell to their lowest point since 2002 yesterday.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eOil producers have tried to limit the fallout.\u003c/strong\u003e On Sunday, OPEC+ reached a historic agreement to cut production in a last-ditch attempt to stabilize prices. That may help a little bit, but there is “no feasible agreement that could cut supply by enough” to counteract the demand collapse, the IEA says. Most analysts agree.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eOne stubborn optimist: \u003c/strong\u003eEnergy data provider Kayrros says the cuts are steep enough to avoid overwhelming storage capacity. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eEurope’s largest economy is ready to emerge from hibernation. German Chancellor Angela Merkel said the country will begin to \u003ca href=\"https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-52299358?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eslowly ease lockdown restrictions\u003c/a\u003e—some shops can open next week and schools will return starting May 4. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe country has suffered more than 3,200 reported COVID-19 deaths. But Merkel said it’s achieved \"fragile intermediate success\" in controlling the pandemic. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThis won’t be your Germany of 2019. The businesses that open will have to follow strict social distancing and hygiene precautions. Germans are \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-germany/germany-edges-out-of-lockdown-with-partial-opening-of-shops-schools-idUSKCN21X0X6?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estrongly encouraged\u003c/a\u003e to wear face masks when riding public transportation or going shopping. And large public gatherings are still banned until Aug. 31. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eEurope is beginning to recover. Spain’s construction and manufacturing workers are back in action, as are many stores in Austria and some in Italy. Kids under 11 are going back to school in Denmark. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eA sobering bottom line, via Merkel: \u003c/strong\u003e“It is a fragile situation in which caution is required, not exuberance.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ While we’re here...\u003c/strong\u003ethe WHO has set \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2020/04/15/834021103/who-sets-6-conditions-for-ending-a-coronavirus-lockdown?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esix conditions\u003c/a\u003e for relaxing coronavirus lockdowns.
